choices.text: Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder
Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests

questions.text: A genetic counsellor is discussing various types of genetic tests with a couple planning for a child. Which of the following statements accurately describes genetic screening? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder

 

Genetic screening/testing

 

  • Genetic testing is a type of medical test that identifies changes in genes, chromosomes, or proteins. 
  • It is a process to analyse blood or skin for the systematic search for persons with a particular genotype in a defined population (usually invasive procedures)
  • In order to locate this faulty gene, scientists search for variations in larger pieces of DNA called "markers", latter are found nearby the DNA and become the basis of genetic screening
  • The results of a genetic test can confirm or rule out a suspected genetic condition or help determine a person's chance of developing or passing on a genetic. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests: Incorrect. Screening tests assess risk and are not as definitive as diagnostic tests, which provide a precise diagnosis.

 

Option C. Screening requires genetic mapping: Incorrect. Genetic screening does not necessarily involve genetic mapping, which is a detailed analysis of the entire genome.

 

Option D. Involve invasive procedures: Incorrect. Screening tests can often be performed using non-invasive methods such as blood or saliva samples, although some genetic tests may require invasive procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genetic screening tests are used to define the risk of passing on a genetic disorder and can help determine the likelihood of developing a genetic condition.
  • They are not as definitive as diagnostic tests and do not necessarily involve invasive procedures or genetic mapping.

questions.text: Which of the following organism is intrinsically resistant to the given drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida krusei: Fluconazole

 

  • Candida krusei is known to have intrinsic resistance to fluconazole, which means that this organism generally does not respond to treatment with fluconazole. This is due to a combination of mechanisms including alterations in the target enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, efflux pump activity, and changes in membrane sterols. Therefore, for infections caused by Candida krusei, alternative antifungal agents such as amphotericin B, echinocandins, or voriconazole are typically considered.
  • In the clinical setting, the intrinsic resistance of Candida krusei to fluconazole is significant, as fluconazole is often used as a first-line agent for the treatment of Candida infections. The presence of Candida krusei may therefore necessitate a shift in the standard therapeutic approach and prompt the use of different antifungal therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus niger: Voriconazole Voriconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that is effective against most species of Aspergillus, including Aspergillus niger. It is often used as a first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis. Therefore, Aspergillus niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus: Micafungin Aspergillus fumigatus is generally susceptible to micafungin. Micafungin belongs to the echinocandin class of antifungal drugs, which are effective against most Aspergillus species, but echinocandins are not the first choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. They are typically used as second-line agents or in combination therapy for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option C. Candida glabrata: Amphotericin B Candida glabrata can be susceptible to amphotericin B, but it is known for having a dose-dependent sensitivity or a reduced susceptibility. Some strains may show resistance, but this is not considered intrinsic resistance. Instead, amphotericin B resistance in C. glabrata can be due to acquired mechanisms.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, necessitating the use of alternative antifungal agents for treatment.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is maintained on anesthesia with halothane. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suxamethonium

 

The scenario described involves a patient undergoing surgery who suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. This is indicative of a condition called Malignant Hyperthermia (MH), which is a rare but potentially life-threatening reaction to certain medications used during anesthesia.

 

In this case, the most likely drug implicated in causing MH is:

 

Suxamethonium (also known as succinylcholine)

 

  • Suxamethonium is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used for muscle relaxation during surgery.
  • However, it is known to be associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals.
  • MH is a severe reaction that can cause a rapid increase in body temperature, muscle rigidity, and other complications.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Doxacurium: Doxacurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used to induce muscle relaxation during surgery. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option C. Atracurium: Atracurium is another non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used in anesthesia. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Rocuronium is also a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Like atracurium and doxacurium, it is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug most likely implicated in causing malignant hyperthermia in the given scenario is suxamethonium (succinylcholine) because it is known to trigger this condition in susceptible individuals.

 

Treatment - Dantrolene sodium and supportive management

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of cellular events of inflammation? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Correct sequence of events during inflammation:

 

  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration

 

CELLULAR CHANGES DURING INFLAMMATION

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of intravascular cellular events during inflammation involves rolling, cytokine-mediated integrin activation, adhesion, and migration.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition pg. 78-79

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory test result of leptospira IM reactivity, now presented with breathlessness, fever, and jaundice that worsened after treatment with penicillin. What is the possible diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction

 

The possible diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR) is a transient clinical phenomenon that occurs in patients infected by spirochetes who undergo antibiotic treatment. The reaction typically occurs within 24 hours of starting antibiotic treatment for spirochete infections, including syphilis, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, and relapsing fever.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • The breakdown of the spirochetes after antibiotic administration releases endotoxins and cytokines into the bloodstream.
  • This causes an acute inflammatory reaction, characterized by the release of inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-6 (IL-6), interleukin-8 (IL-8), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha).

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Symptoms include fever, chills, rigors, myalgia, headache, tachycardia, hyperventilation, and exacerbation of skin lesions.
  • The symptoms usually begin within 2 hours of antibiotic administration and resolve within 24 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resistant leptospirosis: This would present with ongoing symptoms despite appropriate antibiotic treatment, but not typically with acute worsening immediately after starting treatment.

 

Option B. Penicillin allergy: This would typically present with urticaria, pruritus, rash, or anaphylaxis, not with the acute inflammatory symptoms described.

 

Option C. Co-infection with dengue: This would be considered if there were signs and symptoms consistent with dengue, such as high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and hemorrhagic manifestations, but it does not explain the acute worsening after penicillin treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is an acute inflammatory response occurring within 24 hours of initiating antibiotic treatment for spirochete infections, characterized by fever, chills, myalgia, and exacerbation of symptoms due to the release of inflammatory cytokines.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of bronchial asthma in third stage of labor. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carboprost

 

The drug that should be avoided in this patient with a history of bronchial asthma is carboprost since it can cause bronchoconstriction.

 

Carboprost (PGF2α analogue)

 

Action - It increases uterine tone by contracting upper segment of uterus

 

Use - To control postpartum hemorrhage (DOC – Oxytocin).

 

A/E - Vomiting, diarrhea, and bronchoconstriction.

 

Contraindications -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is the first-line drug to prevent and treat PPH and also used in augmentation of labour according to WHO guidelines. Administered by intravenous route and may lead to hypotension and reflex tachycardia.

 

Option C. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a PGE2 analogue used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and in atony treatment. It should be avoided in patients with a history of asthma, glaucoma, or myocardial infarction. One major adverse effect is uterine hyperstimulation.

 

Option D. Methyl ergometrine: Ergot derivatives are used in the control of postpartum uterine bleeding. It is given intramuscularly and is effective within 1-5 minutes. It is given at the time of delivery of the placenta or immediately after if bleeding is significant. Side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in patients with a history of bronchial asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A boy with ASOM underwent treatment for the same. Now he presents with subsidence of pain but persistence of deafness. On examination of TM, the following findings are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secretory otitis media

 

Explanation:

 

The boy has undergone treatment for Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) and now presents with subsidence of pain but persistence of deafness. The otoscopic examination reveals air-fluid levels behind an intact tympanic membrane, indicative of fluid in the middle ear. This condition is known as secretory otitis media (also called otitis media with effusion), where the middle ear is filled with sterile fluid, leading to conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ototoxicity: Ototoxicity refers to damage to the inner ear structures, particularly the hair cells, due to exposure to certain ototoxic drugs (e.g., aminoglycosides, loop diuretics, cisplatin). This results in sensorineural hearing loss and is not characterized by air-fluid levels in the middle ear.

 

Option C. Adhesive otitis media: Adhesive otitis media is characterized by the retraction of the tympanic membrane, which adheres to the medial wall of the middle ear. This condition results from chronic eustachian tube dysfunction and does not typically present with air-fluid levels as seen in secretory otitis media.

 

 

Option D. Tympanosclerosis: Tympanosclerosis involves the formation of calcium plaques within the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane or middle ear due to recurrent infections. This leads to stiffening of the tympanic membrane and conductive hearing loss. The otoscopic findings show calcific deposits, not fluid levels.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory otitis media is characterized by the presence of sterile fluid in the middle ear, resulting in conductive hearing loss, and is often seen following the treatment of ASOM.

choices.text: Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min
Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following measures are associated with an increased life span? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent

 

Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent will increase lifespan.

 

Caloric restriction reduces the severity of oxidative damage as well as the resulting decline in function. It lowers the steady-state concentrations of oxidative damage products in proteins, DNA, and lipids. This is due to a decrease in mitochondrial superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide production and an increase in antioxidant production. Caloric restriction slows the rate of energy metabolism overall.

 

Caloric restriction postpones the onset of age-related diseases like cancer (including lymphomas, breast and prostate cancers), nephropathy, and cataracts. Caloric restriction also reduces the onset of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and the development of autoimmune diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min: While exercise has numerous health benefits and can improve quality of life and reduce the risk of chronic diseases, it has not been directly linked to the same extent of lifespan extension as caloric restriction in scientific studies.

 

Option B. Decrease stress: Reducing stress can improve health outcomes and prevent stress-related diseases, but specific lifespan extension evidence is less robust compared to caloric restriction.

 

Option D. Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors: Proton pump inhibitors are used to treat gastrointestinal conditions like acid reflux and ulcers. They are not associated with increased lifespan and may have adverse effects if used long-term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caloric restriction, by decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent, is associated with an increased lifespan and the postponement of age-related diseases. It reduces oxidative damage, slows metabolism, and mitigates the onset of various chronic conditions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with violaceous plane topped papules associated with pruritus over wrist and antecubital fossae for 2 months. The lesions have a characteristic shiny surface and are arranged in a linear pattern. What is the first line of treatment in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical steroids

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is topical steroids.

 

The patient presents with classic signs of lichen planus, which includes violaceous (purple) plane-topped papules that are intensely pruritic (itchy). These lesions are commonly found on the flexor surfaces such as the wrists and antecubital fossae.

 

Lichen planus is a self-limiting condition that usually resolves spontaneously within about 2 years. However, due to the extreme itching, symptomatic treatment is necessary.

 

Topical steroids are the first-line treatment for localized lichen planus, providing relief from itching and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antifungals: These are not used in the treatment of lichen planus, as it is not a fungal infection.

 

Option B. Oral steroids: While oral steroids can be used in more extensive cases of lichen planus, they are not the first-line treatment for localized lesions.

 

Option D. Phototherapy: This can be used in extensive cases but is not the first-line treatment for localized lichen planus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen planus, characterized by violaceous, pruritic, plane-topped papules with a shiny surface, is best treated initially with topical steroids when the condition is localized. ​

questions.text: WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is related to: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Therapeutic abortion

 

The World Medical Association's (WMA) Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical considerations surrounding therapeutic abortion. This declaration emphasizes that medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) should be conducted under specific conditions to ensure it is ethical and safe.

 

The key focus areas of the Oslo Declaration include:

 

MTP must be done only due to:

 

  1. Health Reasons: Therapeutic abortion should only be performed when it is medically necessary for the health of the patient. This may include physical, mental, or social reasons that could adversely affect the well-being of the patient.
  2. Informed Consent: Both the patient and the healthcare provider must fully understand and agree to the procedure. It is essential that both parties are convinced of the necessity and appropriateness of the abortion.
  3. Legal Compliance: The procedure must comply with the local laws governing abortion in the specific region, territory, or country. Legal regulations vary, and it is crucial to adhere to them.
  4. Competent Personnel: The procedure should be carried out by competent surgeons. If the situation allows, trained professional health workers who are competent and authorized by law can also perform the procedure.

 

These principles ensure that therapeutic abortions are conducted in a manner that prioritizes the safety, rights, and well-being of the patient while adhering to ethical and legal standards.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hunger: The Declaration of Oslo is not related to hunger. Hunger and food security issues are addressed by different international organizations and declarations, but not by this specific WMA declaration.

 

Option B. State of prisoners: The Oslo Declaration does not deal with the treatment or state of prisoners. Other international conventions, like the Geneva Conventions, cover the rights and treatment of prisoners.

 

Option C. Ethics in Medical Research: Although the WMA has issued other declarations related to ethics in medical research, such as the Declaration of Helsinki, Nuremberg code and Belmont report.

 

Additional Information

 

Declaration of Geneva: related to the physician's dedication to humanitarian goals of medicine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical guidelines surrounding therapeutic abortion, emphasizing health reasons, informed consent, legal compliance, and the requirement for competent medical personnel.

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 6

 

Explanation:

 

Instruments used in a cesarean section

 

  • BP handle
  • Allis forceps
  • Artery forceps
  • Doyen retractor
  • Green Armitage forceps
  • Metzenbaum scissors

 

Among the options

 

  • Cusco’s speculum has no role in LSCA It is a vaginal self-retaining speculum with two blades
  • Shirodkar’s uterine clamp is used in gynecological procedures to hold the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that Bard-Parker blade, Doyen's retractor, Allis forceps, and Green Armytage forceps are essential instruments used in a cesarean section, while Cusco's speculum and Shirodkar's uterine clamp are not used in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page no 756

questions.text: A surgical procedure is performed on the great saphenous vein located 2.5 cm anterior to the medial malleolus. Which nerve should be prevented from damage during the ligature? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saphenous nerve

 

The saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body. It accompanies the great saphenous vein, running anterior to the medial malleolus before it supplies sensation to the medial side of the leg and foot. During surgical procedures involving the great saphenous vein, particularly at the site near the medial malleolus, the saphenous nerve is at risk of injury. Damage to this nerve can result in sensory loss along its distribution, which includes the medial aspect of the foot and lower leg.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve: The sural nerve is located posterior to the lateral malleolus and is not involved in the area anterior to the medial malleolus, making it unlikely to be injured during this particular procedure.

 

Option B. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve runs deeper and posterior to the medial malleolus. It is not in close proximity to the great saphenous vein at the described location, so it is not the nerve at risk in this scenario.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: The deep peroneal nerve runs along the anterior compartment of the leg and provides sensation to the web space between the first and second toes. It does not accompany the great saphenous vein and is not at risk in the described procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein near the medial malleolus and is at risk of injury during surgical procedures in this region.

questions.text: Diagnose the condition shown in the following image.  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone that typically results from bacteria, most commonly staphylococcus aureus.
  • It is characterized by persistent pain, swelling, warmth, and redness over the affected area.
  • The infection often leads to chronic discharge from a sinus tract or wound, and systemic symptoms may be less pronounced compared to acute infections.
  • On radiographs or MRI, chronic osteomyelitis may present as:
    • Bone Destruction: There can be areas of bone destruction or loss with possible formation of sequestra (dead bone) and involucrum (new bone formation surrounding the dead bone).
    • Sinus Tracts: Imaging may show draining sinus tracts or soft tissue swelling.
    • Cortical Erosion: There might be cortical erosion or irregularity.

 

 

  • Histopathology: Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by the presence of chronic inflammatory cells, granulation tissue, and sometimes necrotic bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing’s Sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor typically found in children and young adults. It is one of the small round blue cell tumors. Patients usually present with localized pain, swelling, and possibly systemic symptoms like fever. The tumor often affects long bones or the pelvis.  On radiographs or MRI, Ewing’s sarcoma can present as a permeative lesion with ill-defined margins, an onion skin periosteal reaction. It is typically associated with an extensive soft tissue mass, an osteolytic lesion with or without calcifications. Histopathologically, it is characterized by small round blue cells with a characteristic "small round cell" appearance and is often confirmed with immunohistochemical staining and cytogenetic analysis (e.g., EWS-FLI1 fusion gene).

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that primarily affects adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by pain, swelling, and occasionally a palpable mass. It is commonly located around the knee or the metaphysis of long bones. On radiographs or MRI, osteosarcoma may present as mixed osteolytic and osteoblastic (sclerotic) lesions, formation of new bone perpendicular to the cortex due to the aggressive nature of the tumor lifting the periosteum, called as Codman’s triangle, and a soft tissue mass. Histopathologically, it shows pleomorphic osteoblasts producing malignant osteoid or bone matrix. Diagnosis is confirmed through biopsy and histological examination.

 

Codman’s triangle

 

Option D. Acute Osteomyelitis: Acute Osteomyelitis is a recent infection of the bone, usually caused by bacteria. Symptoms include rapid onset of severe pain, swelling, redness, and warmth over the affected area, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever and malaise. On radiographs or MRI, acute osteomyelitis may not show significant bone changes initially, but can later show bone marrow edema and possible periosteal reaction. As the condition progresses, there may be evidence of bone destruction, sequestra formation, or an abscess. Histopathologically, it is typically characterized by acute inflammatory changes with neutrophils and potentially abscess formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is characterized by long-standing infection, typically with a chronic clinical course and imaging findings that reflect bone destruction and chronic inflammation.
  • The given image in the question shows sequestrum and involucrum in the lower end of femur, which are typically characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne’s negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-45 dB

 

The given clinical scenario of hearing loss with a negative Rinne at 256 Hz and 512 Hz and positive Rinne at 1024 Hz indicates air conduction and bone conduction gap of 30-45 dB.

 

  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz tuning fork (TF) but positive for 512Hz tuning fork → approximate hearing loss will be 20-30dB.
  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz & 512Hz TF but positive for 1024Hz TF → approximate hearing loss will be 30–45dB
  • Rinne’s negative for all 256Hz, 512Hz & 1024Hz → approximate hearing loss will be 45-60dB.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with difficulty in breathing and dizziness. He has been undergoing treatment for lung cancer. On examination, breath sounds were reduced over the left inferior-scapular region. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac tamponade

 

The key clues in this scenario include the patient’s history of lung cancer and the reduction in breath sounds over the left inferior-scapular region.

 

Lung cancer is a significant cause of cardiac tamponade due to its potential to invade the pericardium and cause pericardial effusion. Cardiac tamponade occurs when fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, leading to increased pressure on the heart, impairing its ability to pump effectively, and often resulting in symptoms such as difficulty breathing and dizziness.

 

In this case, the patient’s symptoms and history suggest that the lung cancer has likely caused a large pericardial effusion, leading to cardiac tamponade. The reduction in breath sounds over the left inferior-scapular region is consistent with this diagnosis.

 

EWOT sign – In a patient with large pericardial effusion, probably a cardiac tamponade with  reduced breath sounds over the left infrascapular region + added sounds like bronchophony, egophony, bronchial breath sounds, is referred as EWOT sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleural effusion: While lung cancer can also cause pleural effusion, the question's clinical senario and reduction in breath sounds align more closely with cardiac tamponade.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax typically presents with sudden chest pain and shortness of breath, and the physical examination would usually reveal hyperresonance and decreased breath sounds on one side. It does not fit the patient's history of lung cancer and the described examination findings.

 

Option D. Constrictive pericarditis: This condition involves chronic inflammation and thickening of the pericardium, leading to impaired filling of the heart. It is less likely given the acute presentation and the specific mention of lung cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung cancer can lead to cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, impairing the heart's function and causing symptoms such as difficulty breathing and dizziness.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myringotomy

 

Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Myringotomy is most commonly done for serous otitis media in the anteroinferior quadrant radially. Sometimes, grommet insertion is done through the opening made by myringotome in the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septoplasty: This procedure corrects a deviated nasal septum, involving different instruments primarily for reshaping the nasal structure, not for ear-related surgeries.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This is a procedure to repair a perforation of the tympanic membrane but does not typically use a myringotome; instead, it uses tools for patching or grafting the membrane.

 

Option D. Adenoidectomy: This surgery involves the removal of the adenoids located in the upper part of the throat behind the nose, using different instruments like curettes or microdebriders, not a myringotome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The myringotome is crucial for performing a myringotomy, allowing for precise incisions in the tympanic membrane to address issues such as serous otitis media. The instrument's design facilitates targeted, clean cuts to insert grommets if needed.

questions.text: Which of the following local  anaesthetic causes hypertension?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

Cocaine: An ester local anesthetic that is also a powerful central nervous system stimulant. One of the well-known cardiovascular effects of cocaine is hypertension, due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine: is an amide local anesthetic that is used to produce numbness during procedures and for treating various types of pain. It can cause side effects such as dizziness and low blood pressure but is not known for causing hypertension.

 

Option C. Bupivacaine: An amide local anesthetic known for its potent and long-lasting numbing effect. It can cause cardiovascular complications, but like lignocaine, it is more associated with cardiac toxicity rather than hypertension.

 

Option D. Prilocaine: Another amide local anesthetic, similar to lignocaine, and not commonly associated with causing hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cocaine is the local anesthetic known to cause hypertension due to its vasoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhizopus

 

Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect, although Candida is a common opportunistic pathogen, it is more frequently associated with mucocutaneous and systemic infections rather than orbital cellulitis.

 

Option C. Aspergillus: Incorrect, Aspergillus can cause a variety of infections including orbital cellulitis, but it is not the most common cause in the context of diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Option D. Trichophyton: Incorrect, Trichophyton primarily causes skin infections such as ringworm and athlete's foot, and is not typically associated with orbital cellulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhizopus is the predominant fungal pathogen linked with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, underscoring the critical need for prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment in such high-risk groups to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluoroscopy

 

The image provided is a still from a video fluoroscopy study, which is essentially a continuous X-ray video that allows the visualization of dynamic processes in real time, such as swallowing. This technique is used for examining the movement of the pharynx and esophagus. Although the image might appear to be from a barium swallow study, the key distinguishing factor is that it shows only the pharynx, which aligns more with a fluoroscopy study rather than a traditional barium swallow.

 

In a barium swallow, the entire esophagus is visualized, whereas fluoroscopy focuses more on the pharyngeal phase of swallowing. Therefore, even though both fluoroscopy and barium swallow are correct interpretations of the image, fluoroscopy is the more precise answer since it captures the pharyngeal motion observed in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barium swallow: A barium swallow involves the patient swallowing barium to coat the esophagus, making it visible on X-rays. However, this image specifically shows the pharyngeal phase, which is more consistent with fluoroscopy rather than a complete barium swallow study.

 

Option C. Acid ingestion: Acid ingestion refers to the damage to the esophagus or stomach lining due to acid, which would present differently on imaging. This condition does not correspond to the observed fluoroscopy of swallowing.

 

Option D. Alkali ingestion: Similar to acid ingestion, alkali ingestion would show chemical burns or strictures but would not be directly visualized in a swallowing motion study like fluoroscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroscopy is a dynamic X-ray imaging technique used to visualize the motion of the pharynx and esophagus during swallowing. It provides real-time assessment, unlike a static barium swallow.

questions.text: Pneumoconiosis associated with exposure to cotton dust is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Byssinosis.

 

Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease," is a type of pneumoconiosis specifically associated with exposure to cotton dust. It is an occupational lung disease that typically affects workers in the textile industry, including those involved in spinning, weaving, and processing cotton. The inhalation of cotton dust can cause the airways to become constricted, leading to symptoms such as chest tightness, coughing, and wheezing, particularly at the start of the workweek, which is sometimes referred to as "Monday fever."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bagassosis: This is a pneumoconiosis caused by exposure to bagasse, the fibrous material left over after sugarcane or sorghum stalks are crushed to extract their juice. It is commonly seen in workers in the sugar industry.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Also known as "black lung disease," this condition is caused by the inhalation of coal dust. It primarily affects coal miners and results in the accumulation of carbon particles in the lungs.

 

Option D. Silicosis: Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of silica dust, which is commonly found in industries like cement, glass manufacturing, and stone cutting. It leads to inflammation and scarring in the lungs.

 

Note –

 

Asbestosis: Caused by exposure to asbestos dust, asbestosis is a serious condition that leads to lung fibrosis. It is prevalent among workers in the cement industry and is particularly noted in shipyard workers due to the historical use of asbestos in ship construction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of Pneumoconiosis:

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with a history of GTCS presented with 4-5 episodes of seizures, and seizures are present for more than 45 minutes. What will be the most appropriate management for this patient?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam

 

Explanation:

 

In the management of status epilepticus (SE), the first line of treatment involves benzodiazepines. Lorazepam is preferred due to its rapid onset and longer duration of action compared to other benzodiazepines like diazepam or midazolam.

 

  • First line treatment: Intravenous (IV) lorazepam (standard dose of 4 mg in adults; different doses for children).
  • If seizures persist after the first dose of lorazepam, it can be repeated once.
  • Second line treatment: If seizures continue after two doses of lorazepam, IV anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) are administered. Options include IV phenytoin, fosphenytoin, levetiracetam, valproate, or lacosamide.
  • If still persist, intubate the patient, continuous EEG monitoring and give IV General anaesthesia (IV midazolam or IV propofol infusion)

 

In this case, following lorazepam with levetiracetam is consistent with current guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levetiracetam followed by valproate: Levetiracetam is a second-line treatment, not first-line.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine followed by lorazepam: Carbamazepine is not typically used in the acute management of SE.

 

Option D. Valproate followed by gabapentin: Valproate can be used as a second-line treatment, but gabapentin is not typically used for SE management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first line of management for status epilepticus is IV lorazepam, followed by IV antiepileptic drugs like levetiracetam if seizures persist.

questions.text: Vessel A has a length of L and diameter of D and vessel B has 2L and 2D. Considering, the flow is laminar through both the cylinders, the flow through B is how many times as much as the flow through A? (INICETMAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 times

 

Flow through B will be 8 times more than the flow through A.

According to Poiseuille Hagen formula,

 

F= AP X π/8 x 1/n x r/L

F= flow

AP = pressure difference between two ends of the tube

П = viscosity

r-radius of the tube

L-length of the tube

Hence flow directly varies to the 4th power of radius and inversely varies to length.

 

Flow through B = (2r)4/2L = 2*2*2*2/ 2 = 16/2= 8 times

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of the radius (𝑟4r4) and inversely proportional to the length (𝐿L) of the vessel.

questions.text: Liver produces KB but cannot use KB due to absence of which enzyme:  (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thiophorase

 

The liver lacks the enzyme thiophorase (succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase) necessary to utilize the ketone bodies it produces. This enzyme is required to convert acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA, which can then be further metabolized into two molecules of acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA is a central molecule in energy metabolism and can enter the citric acid cycle (also known as the Kreb’s cycle) to produce ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiolase: It is the common enzyme of Ketone body synthesis and KB utilization.

 

Option C. HMG CoA synthase: HMG CoA synthase is RLE of ketone bodies synthesis in the liver. It is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA), a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol and ketone bodies. However, the absence of HMG CoA synthase would impact the overall synthesis of ketone bodies rather than their utilization.

 

Option D. HMG CoA reductase: HMG CoA reductase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of mevalonate, which is a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol. However, the absence of HMG CoA reductase in the liver would not directly affect the utilization of ketone bodies. It would primarily impact the synthesis of cholesterol and other downstream products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver plays a crucial role in ketone body metabolism. During periods of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake, the liver produces ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through a process called ketogenesis. These ketone bodies are then released into the bloodstream and can be used as an alternative fuel source by various tissues, including the brain, heart, and skeletal muscles.

questions.text: A primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation presents to you with profuse vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure and glucose levels are within normal limits. Placental implantation at which of the following sites can cause this? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal os

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of placenta previa which is caused due to placental implantation at the internal os.
  • Although the term placenta previa is diagnosed after 28 weeks, it can present with profuse bleeding at earlier gestational ages also.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fallopian tube: This will not present as profuse vaginal bleeding at 22 weeks. This will present at a much earlier gestational age (6-8 weeks) and presents with abdominal pain (ruptured ectopic), vaginal bleeding (not profuse) and amenorrhoea (6-8 weeks)

 

Option C. Ovarian: Presents like an ectopic in the fallopian tube

 

Option D. Abdominal: This has varied presentations, but doesn’t present with profuse vaginal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placental implantation at the internal os, causing placenta previa, can lead to profuse vaginal bleeding during the second trimester of pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page 657, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hand, foot, and mouth disease

 

Vesicular rash is seen in hand, foot, and mouth disease.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute viral illness that presents as a vesicular eruption in the mouth, but it can also involve the hands, feet, buttocks, and/or genitalia. Caused by Coxsackie A virus. The presence of vesicular rashes in these specific locations is a hallmark of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In Dengue Fever, the initial rash is a transient flushing erythema of face that typically occurs shortly before or within the first 24-48 hours of the onset of symptoms and is thought to be the result of capillary dilatation. The second rash usually occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and it is characterized by asymptomatic maculopapular or morbilliform eruption.

 

Option C. The rash associated with the Zika virus is a combination of flat blotches (macules) and raised tiny reddish bumps like papules (not as petechiae)

 

Option D. In roseola infantum, upon rapid defervescence of the fever around days three to five, small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules will develop. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. The rash is typically nonpruritic, blanching and can persist from one to two days. Caused by HHV 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicular rash is specifically seen in Hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. Identify the device.  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ex-Press™ implant

 

The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

 

It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

  • A tiny stainless-steel implant called Ex-PRESS is used to treat glaucoma.
  • It is implanted during a modified trabeculectomy underneath a scleral flap.
  • Hypotony-related complications are less common than with conventional trabeculectomy.
  • By creating a communication between the anterior chamber and the sub-space/sub-conjunctival Tennon's space, glaucoma drainage devices enable aqueous outflow.
  • While formerly only used in high-risk patients or after a failed trabulectomy, these devices are gaining popularity.
  • The commonly used devices are as follows:
    • ﻿﻿Shunts using episcleral explants
    • ﻿﻿Ahmed glaucoma valve- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Molteno implant- Polypropelene plate and silicone plate
    • ﻿﻿Baerveldt implant- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Mini-shunts
    • ﻿﻿Ex-Press™M Mini-Shunt- Stainless steel
    • ﻿﻿iStent®- Titanium

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ahmed Glaucoma Valve:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Contains a valve mechanism to prevent hypotony.
  • Popular for its ease of implantation and reliable outcomes.
  • Used in cases requiring controlled aqueous humor outflow but differs in design and function from the Ex-Press™ implant

 

Option C. Molteno Implant:

  • Made of polypropylene plate and silicone plate.
  • One of the earliest glaucoma drainage devices, offering various plate sizes.

 

Option D. Baerveldt Implant:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Designed to provide large surface area for filtration.
  • Requires ligation to prevent early postoperative hypotony.
  • Also used for glaucoma management

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant is a minimally invasive device used during modified trabeculectomy to enhance aqueous drainage and reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma. This implant is characterized by its stainless-steel construction and effectiveness in controlling glaucoma with fewer hypotony-related complications.

choices.text: Increase in PR interval

questions.text: What is the likely ECG changes noted with the use of new anti-tubercular drug bedaquiline: (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) QT prolongation

 

The likely ECG change noted with the use of bedaquiline is QT prolongation. This prolongation of the QT interval can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including a specific type known as Torsades de Pointes. Monitoring of the QT interval is important during bedaquiline therapy, and caution is advised, especially in patients with pre-existing cardiac conditions or those taking other medications that can also prolong the QT interval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in PR interval: An increase in the PR interval is not a common ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Option C. ST segment elevation: ST segment elevation is not a typical ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Option D. QRS widening: QRS widening is not a common ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

QT prolongation is a well-documented ECG change associated with the use of bedaquiline. It is one of the notable side effects of this drug.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. His urine analysis shows RBC casts without any significant findings. The likely diagnosis is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgA vasculitis

 

The clinical scenario described in the question is highly suggestive of IgA vasculitis, which was previously known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). This condition is characterized by the involvement of multiple organs, including the gastrointestinal tract, joints, skin, and kidneys. The hallmark features of IgA vasculitis include:

 

  1. Gastrointestinal Involvement: Patients often present with abdominal pain, which may be due to vasculitis of the mesenteric vessels. In severe cases, it can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
  2. Joint Involvement: Arthralgia or arthritis is common, particularly affecting the knees and ankles.
  3. Skin Involvement: The presence of palpable purpura, typically on the lower extremities, is a key clinical feature. This is a type of non-thrombocytopenic purpura, indicating that the purpura is not due to low platelet counts.
  4. Renal Involvement: The presence of RBC casts in the urine analysis indicates glomerulonephritis, which is a common renal manifestation of IgA vasculitis.

 

IgA vasculitis is primarily an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis. The deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes in the small vessels leads to the inflammation and damage seen in the affected organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behcet disease: This condition is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, as well as uveitis. It does not typically present with the combination of symptoms described in this case, particularly the specific renal involvement with RBC casts.

 

Option B. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's): This is a form of vasculitis that typically involves the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys, but it does not present with palpable purpura or the same pattern of multi-organ involvement seen in IgA vasculitis.

 

Option D. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus): SLE can present with a wide variety of symptoms due to its multi-system involvement. However, the specific combination of abdominal pain, joint pain, palpable purpura, and RBC casts is more characteristic of IgA vasculitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgA vasculitis, previously known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, is characterized by abdominal pain, joint pain, palpable purpura, and renal involvement with RBC casts. It is an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes develops a UTI, which gets complicated with hypotension that is resistant to IV fluids. Which of the following antibiotics can be used? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piperacillin-Tazobactam

 

The patient with diabetes has developed a urinary tract infection (UTI) complicated by hypotension resistant to IV fluids, indicating septic shock. In cases of septic shock, it is critical to start with empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics. These antibiotics are designed to cover a wide range of potential pathogens until the specific causative organism can be identified and targeted.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics suitable for such severe infections include:

 

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam
  • Carbapenems like Meropenem or Imipenem
  • Certain third-generation cephalosporins like Ceftazidime

 

In this case, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is chosen because it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers many of the common pathogens responsible for severe infections and septic shock. Although a combination of Meropenem with Vancomycin would be ideal, the given options do not include Meropenem. Therefore, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is the best choice among the provided options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This antibiotic is generally not sufficient for treating severe infections or septic shock due to its narrower spectrum of activity compared to Piperacillin-Tazobactam.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: While Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, it is not as broad-spectrum as Ceftazidime and does not provide the same coverage needed for septic shock.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: This antibiotic is typically used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections and is not effective for severe systemic infections or septic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of septic shock, especially in a patient with diabetes and complicated UTI, broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin-Tazobactam are critical for empirical therapy.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with hoarseness of voice with a history of significant weight loss. On laryngoscopy, ulceroproliferative growth involving the left vocal fold is seen, as shown below. The vocal cord is fixed. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

 

Explanation:  


The clinical presentation (hoarseness of voice, weight loss) and the laryngoscopic findings (ulceroproliferative growth with fixed vocal cord) suggest advanced glottic carcinoma. The fixed vocal cord indicates at least T3 stage, as it suggests tumor infiltration into the paraglottic space or fixation due to deeper invasion. Weight loss in an elderly patient further supports an advanced stage malignancy.

 

This is the preferred treatment for T3 or T4 laryngeal cancers, especially when the vocal cords are fixed, and there is a high likelihood of regional spread. If the patient has significant lymph node involvement or is symptomatic (e.g., weight loss), a neck dissection is warranted along with total laryngectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical Radiotherapy: Radical radiotherapy is usually preferred for early-stage laryngeal cancers (T1 or T2) with mobile vocal cords. It is less effective for advanced stages (T3 or T4) due to higher chances of recurrence.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the primary treatment for advanced laryngeal carcinoma unless the patient is unsuitable for surgery or radiation. It is primarily used for palliative care or in cases with distant metastasis.

 

Option D. Concurrent Chemoradiation: Concurrent chemoradiation is a consideration for organ preservation in advanced laryngeal cancers. However, for patients with a fixed vocal cord and significant weight loss, total laryngectomy provides better local control and survival outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:


For advanced glottic carcinoma with vocal cord fixation (T3/T4) and evidence of regional spread, the best treatment option is Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

questions.text: What type of MRI image is given below? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B Susceptibility weighted image

 

Explanation:

 

Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) is an MRI sequence which is sensitive to compounds that can distort the local magnetic field.

 

Type of Gradient echo sequence / T2* sequence 

 

Black dots s/o hemorrhage known as blooming

 

Sequence of choice for DAI (diffuse axonal injury)   

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proton density image: Typically used to provide good anatomical detail and contrast of soft tissues, not specifically sensitive to magnetic susceptibilities.

 

Option C. Gradient echo image: While SWI uses gradient echo sequences, it specifically exploits phase data and magnitude data to enhance the visibility of substances affecting magnetic susceptibility.

 

Option D. Inversion recovery image: This MRI technique is used to suppress or enhance certain tissue types based on their relaxation properties, which is not indicative of the contrast seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) is particularly useful in detecting and differentiating substances in the brain that affect magnetic susceptibility, such as iron and blood, making it an excellent choice for identifying microhemorrhages and assessing diffuse axonal injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in MMR?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Death due to RTA

 

Explanation:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths divided by the number of live births, multiplied by a factor of 100,000. Maternal death is defined as the death of a mother at any time during pregnancy, labour, delivery, or within 42 days after delivery, provided it is related to maternity or its complications.

 

Deaths due to preeclampsia, ectopic pregnancy, and within 14 days post-partum are included in the calculation of MMR, as they are related to maternity or its complications.

 

However, Deaths due to road traffic accidents (RTA) are not included in the MMR calculation, as they are not directly related to maternity or its complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death due to preeclampsia - This option is correct because deaths due to preeclampsia, a pregnancy-related complication, are included in the MMR calculation.

 

Option C. Death due to ectopic pregnancy - This option is correct because deaths due to ectopic pregnancy, a pregnancy-related condition, are included in the MMR calculation.

 

Option D. Death on 14th day post-partum - This option is correct because deaths within 42 days after delivery are included in the MMR calculation, which includes the 14th day post-partum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) includes deaths related to maternity or its complications during pregnancy, labour, delivery, or within 42 days after delivery. Deaths due to causes unrelated to maternity, such as road traffic accidents, are not included in the MMR calculation.

questions.text: What is the reservoir of leishmaniasis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Man

 

Explanation:

 

The reservoir of visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kalazar or Indian kala-azar, is humans.

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar) is caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani.
  • The vector responsible for transmitting the disease is the sandfly (Phlebotomus species).

 

 

  • The reservoir host of the disease is humans (man).

 

Other 3 options are incorrect

 

Educational Objective:

 

For visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar or Indian kala-azar), the reservoir host is humans.

questions.text: In POP Q staging, the reference point taken is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hymen

 

Explanation:

 

The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system is a standardized method for assessing and quantifying the severity of pelvic organ prolapse. The reference point in POP-Q staging is the hymen. All measurements in the POP-Q system are taken relative to the hymen, which serves as a fixed anatomical landmark.

 

 

The POP-Q system involves six specific points and three measurements:

 

 

Points:

 

Aa: A point on the anterior vaginal wall, 3 cm proximal to the hymen.

 

Ba: The most distal position of any part of the anterior vaginal wall.

 

C: The cervix or the vaginal cuff after hysterectomy.

 

Ap: A point on the posterior vaginal wall, 3 cm proximal to the hymen.

 

Bp: The most distal position of any part of the posterior vaginal wall.

 

D: The posterior fornix or the deepest part of the vaginal vault.

 

Measurements:

 

GH (Genital Hiatus): Distance from the external urethral meatus to the posterior hymen.

 

PB (Perineal Body): Distance from the posterior hymen to the mid-anal opening.

 

TVL (Total Vaginal Length): Distance from the hymen to the posterior fornix or vaginal apex.

 

Other 3 Options: Not used as a reference point in POP-Q staging.

 

Educational objective:

 

In the POP-Q system, the hymen is used as the reference point for all measurements and staging of pelvic organ prolapse.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in Opioid Substitution Therapy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Buprenorphine


Opioid Substitution Therapy (OST) is a treatment given during the maintenance phase of opioid dependence. The goal is to reduce the harm associated with opioid use, such as the risks of HIV, Hepatitis, and illegal activities related to drug procurement. In OST, opioids like buprenorphine or methadone are used to replace more harmful opioids like heroin or morphine. These substitutions help control withdrawal symptoms and prevent relapse while allowing the patient to live a more stable life. Buprenorphine, being a partial opioid agonist, is preferred because it reduces cravings and withdrawal symptoms without the euphoric effects associated with other opioids, making it an effective substitute in OST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonidine: Clonidine is not used in OST because it is not an opioid. It may be used to manage withdrawal symptoms during detoxification but does not replace opioids during the maintenance phase.

 

Option B. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist, meaning it blocks the effects of opioids rather than substituting them. It can be used in the maintenance phase of opioid dependence but is not part of OST because it does not substitute one opioid for another.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used primarily to reverse opioid overdose. It is not used in OST because it does not have the substitutive effects needed for maintenance therapy in opioid dependence.

 

Educational Objective:


Opioid Substitution Therapy involves replacing a harmful opioid with a safer opioid like oral buprenorphine or methadone during the maintenance phase of treatment.

questions.text: Under the sustainable development goal given by United Nations target for reduction of MMR by the year 2030 is (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 70/lac LB

 

  • The United Nations has set 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be achieved by 2030.
  • Goal number 3, which is directly health-related, focuses on "Health and well-being for all." Under this goal – 
    • Target 3.1 specifically states that the Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) should be reduced below 70 maternal deaths per 1 lakh live births by 2030.
    • Target 3.2 – U5MR <25 per 1 lakh live births by 2030.
      -  NNMR <12 per 1000 live births

 

Educational Objective:

 

The United Nations' Sustainable Development Goal target 3.1 aims to reduce the global Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) to below 70 maternal deaths per 1 lakh (100,000) live births by the year 2030.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for delusional disorder?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Young age

 

This is not a typical risk factor for delusional disorder. It usually starts in middle or late adult life.

 

Other Options:

 

Delusional disorder typically begins in middle or late adult life, and it is uncommon in young individuals.

 

Option A. Recent immigration: True. Recent immigration or cultural isolation can be associated with the development of certain types of delusions.

 

Option B. Social isolation: True. Individuals who are socially isolated are at increased risk for the development of delusional disorder.

 

Option C. Family history: True. Having a family history of delusional disorder can increase the risk of developing the condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorder typically begins in middle to late adulthood. It is characterized by development of a single delusion or a set of related delusions, which are usually persistent and sometimes are life long.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 331.

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.text: An elderly male patient who received a kidney transplant a decade ago is presently under immunosuppressive treatment. He reports experiencing a persistent cough and shortness of breath over the past week. Microscopic examination of his sputum reveals the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. What is the probable diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invasive candidiasis

 

  • The presented clinical scenario, coupled with the microscopy revealing gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae, strongly indicates the presence of invasive candidiasis.
  • Candida albicans has a unique ability to transform frequently between three phenotypic forms in the tissue: yeast, pseudohyphae, true hyphae. This property helps it to evade host defense system.
  • Invasive candidiasis results from hematogenous or local spread of the fungi.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor shows, broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching.

 

Option B. Aspergillus shows septate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive candidiasis is characterized by the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae in tissue or clinical specimens, especially in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Explanation:

 

  • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase.
  • It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by a mousy or musty odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites.

 

Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase causes isovaleric acidemia, which is associated with a rancid, cheesy, or sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.

 

Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase leads to tyrosinemia type I, which is characterized by a boiled cabbage or rotten mushrooms odor due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: While doing endoscopy a constriction is noted at the level of 25 cm from incisors. Identify the probable cause of the constriction? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arch of aorta

 

During an endoscopy, constrictions of the esophagus can be identified at specific distances from the upper incisors. These constrictions are due to anatomical structures that come in close proximity to or cross the esophagus. At the level of 25 cm from the incisors, the probable cause of constriction is the arch of the aorta.

 

Anatomical Constrictions of the Esophagus:

 

  1. Junction with Cricopharynx (15 cm from incisors):
    • The first constriction occurs where the esophagus joins the cricopharynx, at approximately 15 cm from the upper incisors.
  2. Crossed by Arch of Aorta and Left Bronchus (25 cm from incisors):
    • The second constriction is due to the arch of the aorta and the left principal bronchus crossing the esophagus. This occurs at about 25 cm from the upper incisors.
  3. Diaphragmatic Hiatus (40 cm from incisors):
    • The third constriction occurs where the esophagus passes through the diaphragm, at around 40 cm from the upper incisors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Upper Bronchus: The left principal (main) bronchus, not the left upper bronchus, can contribute to the constriction at 25 cm from the incisors.

 

Option C. Right Upper Bronchus: The right upper bronchus does not cause a constriction in the esophagus.

 

Option D. Right Lower Bronchus: The right lower bronchus does not cause a constriction in the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constriction of the esophagus observed at 25 cm from the upper incisors during an endoscopy is most commonly due to the crossing of the esophagus by the arch of the aorta and the left principal bronchus.
